options: Respect her decision not to inform her parents, discuss her options and if she wishes refer her for a termination of pregnancy
Explore why she does not want her parents to know, discuss her options and if she wishes refer her for a termination of pregnancy
Ask her to go for a course of counselling before referring for a termination
Ask the patient to wait in the waiting room whilst you phone her mother and ask her what she wants to happen
Refer her for a termination of pregnancy but let her known you have a legal duty to inform her mother
questions:
A 15-year-old girl presents to surgery with her friend requesting an abortion. She has missed her last three periods and performed a pregnancy test which was positive. Her boyfriend is also 15-years-old. Due to her gestation it is likely she will require a surgical termination of pregnancy. She does not want to inform her parents.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
As she is a minor she is able to consent to medical intervention but not able to refuse it. Regardless of her age she is still entitled to be treated confidentially.

If she goes ahead with a surgical termination of pregnancy it will require inpatient treatment and it is unlikely she would be able to keep this from her parents. It is best to gently explore this issue from the outset and this is therefore the best option. Doctors who have an ethical objection to abortion should refer her on to another doctor.

Referring her for a course of counselling will only delay an already late abortion.

As discussed previously the patient has a right to confidentiality.

questions:
You are caring for a local cardiology consultant's father who has been admitted following a myocardial infarction. He bleeps you from the switchboard and asks how his father is doing. You recognise his voice on the phone.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The main nub of this question relates to confidentiality. You cannot give details over the phone to anyone, even his son, without the patient's express permission. Whilst it may be presumed that this is what the patient would want it is impossible to be sure of the family dynamics.

If the patient has given permission and you are sure you are speaking to the son then giving relevant details is the best option. Asking the consultant to come in as an option but may not be necessary if the previous conditions are met. Saying he is 'doing fine' is unlikely to satisfy a consultant cardiologist.

Giving details without first getting permission from the patient is breaking confidentiality, however well intentioned.

Taking general cardiology advice from a relative is unprofessional and would almost certainly involve discussing patient details if it was to be meaningful.

Involving a relative in the management of a patient (by faxing the clinical details) is inappropriate and the worst option.

options: Tell her you have a legal and professional duty to phone 999
Explore her fears regarding hospital admission
Request a domiciliary psychiatrist to visit her and assess capacity
Phone 999 anonymously to maintain doctor-patient relationship
Do not admit the patient but call to see her later in the afternoon
questions:
A home visit is requested for a 78-year-old woman. On arrival you find that she has a hemiparesis resulting in left-sided weakness. She understands that she has probably had a stroke. You go to call 999 but she stops you saying she won't go into hospital. She is coherent and there is no evidence of confusion during the consultation. Her husband tries to persuade her but she is adamant.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The decision of the patient may seem illogical to you given the severity of her condition. You will also have concerns as to how she will be able to cope at home. There is, however, no suggestion from the history that she is mentally incapacitated and hence her autonomous decision must be respected.

She may have had a particularly traumatic previous stay in hospital or may have lost a relative in hospital recently. It is therefore worthwhile spending time to explore her fears. If she still refuses then you must respect her decision but it is sensible to revisit her to ensure there has been no deterioration and give her a chance to change her mind. There is no evidence of psychiatric illness, regardless of how illogical or reckless her decision may seem.

Phoning 999 is the worst option as it does not respect the patient's wishes.

options: Remove the information from the computer notes, print it out and place in the paper notes to avoid accidental browsing
Explain that you are not allowed to remove such material from the medical notes

questions:
You are a GP registrar. During a consultation with a 25-year-old woman she asks you to remove from the records any mention of her being on the contraceptive pill when she was 14-years-old. She is concerned as her mother works as a receptionist at the practice and may see her records.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Difficult one. Medical notes can only be amended if the previous entry was false. This is not the case here so the record of her contraceptive pill use should not be removed. Such information may of course be relevant clinically in the future as well. Exploring why she is concerned may reveal underlying issues and allow you to allay her fears.

If the information is removed from the computer notes and printed out then it will not available during future consultations. Staff are already bound by confidentiality so asking her mother to sign a confidentiality clause is unnecessary.

options: Double check all of Mark's prescription charts to ensure that he hasn't made any mistakes
Ignore the situation
Ask Mark for some cannabis to help you de-stress

questions:
You are a F2 working in the ENT department. Your colleague and good friend Mark is the other F2 on the ward. For the last few weeks you notice that Mark's behaviour has changed. He appears tired and stressed. He looks distracted and has on occasion snapped at the nurses. On a night out, you notice him smoking cannabis and you suspect this is the cause of his behaviour change.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
It is important to recognise when a colleague is struggling and may be turning to drugs or alcohol to deal with this. This is especially vital when the behaviour is impacting on patient safety. Firstly, speak to Mark about what you have witnessed as it allows you to get his side of the story (option 5). This behaviour is not typical for Mark so it may be useful to ask him if anything has changed in the last few weeks that could be contributing to this (option 7). It is then important to make Mark aware that his drug habit may be affecting his work and he should seek help from his GP or local drugs and alcohol team (option 6).

Speaking to Mark's educational supervisor is an overreaction at this stage and may have serious consequences for him (option 8). It is not your duty to check Mark's prescriptions. This may impact on your performance at work as you are doubling your own workload (option 2). Asking him for some cannabis is clearly incorrect and illegal (option 3). Ignoring the situation is dangerous as you may be indirectly affecting patient safety by not raising a legitimate concern (option 1).

options: Apologise for the delay and listen to the concerns raised
Provide Jim and his family with a leaflet on the complaints procedure
Explain that there is a clinical need for other people to be seen before Jim
Tell Jim and his family that you have done all you can and the fault lies with the radiology department

questions:
Jim is a 75-year-old gentleman on your general medical ward. He was admitted with abdominal pain which transpired to be from hypercalcaemia secondary to lung cancer. When discussing this diagnosis you tell Jim and his family that a PET scan would be arranged for the same day. Two hours later the radiology department contact you to tell you that they are short staffed and have had many urgent cases today and so will not be able to see Jim until tomorrow. You tell Jim's family that there will be a delay to the scan and they react negatively, with his son becoming angry.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes: It is appropriate to apologise as the family is worried and upset. Explaining the cause of the delay is also important but concerns should be listened to first. It may be helpful to tell the relatives that the information given was correct at the time but arrangements may change quickly in hospital due to the severity of other patients so that they don't feel ignored or forgotten, however, this is not appropriate as listening and responding to their specific concerns. If they feel a complaint is still warranted then providing information on how to complain would be appropriate, however, they may be satisfied just by you giving time and understanding to their situation. It is not fair to blame radiology as they are responding to clinical needs across the hospital.

options: Ignore her and walk off the ward to avoid inflaming the situation
Tell the nurse you do feel it is inappropriate for her to shout at you
Tell her to stick to nursing and ask for her Nursing and Midwifery Council number
Rewrite the drug card but tell the ward sister you'll be requesting a meeting to discuss what has happened
Phone the consultant yourself and ask him for advice on what to do
questions:
You are working as a junior doctor on a medical ward. It is around 1 pm and you are walking off the ward to get lunch. The ward sister starts shouting at you saying 'where do you think you're going', 'you're not going anywhere until this drug card is rewritten'. After reviewing the drug card you see that none of the medications are due again until the evening and you tell the ward sister you will do it after lunch. She says that is not good enough and threatens to phone your consultant, calling him by his first name.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Not rewriting the drug card will in no way affect patient care. The behaviour of the nurse is therefore unwarranted and rude. The key is to handle the situation in a way which will not make matters worse as it is likely that you will have to work together in the future.

The best option is to calmly tell the nurse that you feel her actions are inappropriate. This behaviour is not acceptable in the workplace.

Rewriting the drug card immediately will placate the nurse but will probably lead to further problems in the future. A line has to be drawn somewhere. Her bullying behaviour is unacceptable.

Getting the consultant involved immediately is an inferior option as the nurse is clearly already wound-up and will pressure the consultant to side with her.

Simply ignoring her is likely to antagonise the situation and threatening/confrontational behaviour is never a good option.

options: Take her on a tour of the ward showing her patients with amputated legs or those on dialysis as an incentive to get better control
Have a chat after the ward round about why she thinks her control is so bad
Write a letter to her GP advising him/her of your concerns
Take no action as it is her decision whether she takes her medication or complies with treatment

questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in general medicine. A 19-year-old female who has type 1 diabetes mellitus is admitted with her fourth episode of diabetic ketoacidosis in the past two months. You suspect she runs her sugars high to keep her weight down. She is generally non-compliant and often self-discharges after 24 hours.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Managing young diabetic patients may be frustrating but needs to be approached in an empathetic manner. Taking time to explore why her control is so bad is the best response in this scenario. The GP should hopefully have a long term relationship with the patient and may be in a position to address these problems.

Taking no action ignores the problem. Trying to scare her by showing her patients with complications is a poor option not least because it fails to respect the privacy of the other patients.

Telling her she is wasting NHS resources is uncaring and unprofessional. Telling her not to turn up at hospital again is indefensible from an ethical and medicolegal perspective.

options: Ignore the consultant's request and do not book the procedure
During the ward round, inform the consultant that Thomas does not want any invasive procedure
Book the procedure and inform Thomas later that it is in his best interests to have it
After the ward round, ask the consultant whether the procedure is necessary
Seek advice from another senior doctor
questions:
You are reviewing a patient, Thomas, with your consultant in a ward round. Thomas who is 75 years old this year is very unwell and frail but still has full capacity. Your consultant recommends an endoscopy to investigate the cause of his illness. He asks you to book the procedure now urgently. You remember Thomas telling you that he does not want any invasive procedures.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
B is most appropriate and immediate as it deals with the problem directly. If the patient has provided specific information as to what interventions he will and will not consent to in a hospital, it is essential that this is conveyed immediately to the consultant. This is to prevent the patient from undergoing any test to which they do not consent.

D ensures that the patient's decision is eventually discussed with the consultant, but it shouldn't be delayed. This is because a ward round might take hours and this means that the patient might have undergone the unwanted procedures before the ward round has finished.

E may be helpful but this is an indirect way of addressing the issue. Most consultants would want to be aware of this information immediately and it wouldn't be confrontational in this context, hence you do not have to address this concern indirectly.

A although you are advocating the patient's request, you shouldn't ignore a consultant's request. The least you could do is to explain to them why. Moreover, there might be other non-invasive alternative investigations available, simply ignoring the request means that no other investigations for the patient will be done as well.

C is least appropriate. This is mainly because the patient has already voiced out that he does not want any invasive procedure conducted on him and he still has the full capacity to make decisions. We must not ignore it as endoscopy is indeed an invasive procedure. We should not book the procedure before you try to speak to the patient again regarding this matter.

title: GMC: Consent - Making decisions about investigations and treatment
body:
The GMC provides in-depth guidance on gaining consent from patients for treatment. When referring to treatment, not just invasive or dangerous procedures such as surgery are taken into account but all forms of treatment including changes to medication or how to investigate a condition. The guidance explains how and what information should be shared with patients to gain consent, who can make decisions on their behalf if a patient cannot and how consent is expressed and recorded.

Providing information:
  • You should explain all the available treatment options to the patient and the benefits and risks of each treatment
  • If you think a treatment is more appropriate you should make a recommendation but ensure you do not bias the patient or coerce them into choosing your preference for treatment
  • When discussing the risks of a treatment you should provide information regarding any risks which would be relevant to the patient; this may be both because they are serious but rare or because they are common but less significant
  • You are obliged to ensure the patient is aware of the risks of a procedure unless they have specifically asked not to be informed; do not assume they would not want to know
  • Even when patients request that information is withheld, you must still ensure that they are aware of the risks associated with any treatment so consent can be obtained
  • You can only withhold information when it would cause 'significant harm' to the patient when giving it; there needs to be evidence, not just a doctor's feeling that it would upset or dissuade a patient
  • You should answer any questions honestly and as fully as you can, even if you think this will result in them withdrawing consent for a procedure

Explaining risks:
  • The discussion should be tailored to the individual and risks adjusted based on their co-morbidities and personal background as appropriate
  • You must always explain side-effects and possible complications of a treatment as well as the risk of failure of treatment

Obtaining and recording consent:
  • You must document in the medical records that a patient has consented to a treatment based on the information given to them; you must record the benefits and risks you have explained
  • This must be done both for trivial treatments such as a new oral medication as well as more significant treatments such as surgical procedures
  • Written consent should be obtained for procedures with significant risk or significant impact on the patient's social situation to formally document the conversation regarding benefits and risks. This should be in addition to recording in the medical records that they have given consent
  • You are legally required to gain written consent for fertility treatment
  • Where possible, the patient should be provided with written information regarding the risks and benefits discussed if the treatment is significant; this may include a copy of a consent form or clinic letter or a leaflet with further information
  • In the case of patients under 16, consent must be sought from the parents and their written consent must be documented

Non-competent patients:
  • Any patient who cannot consent for themselves, either due to a reduced conscious level or a cognitive impairment, can still have treatment in their best interests
  • The reasons for carrying out the procedure must be clearly documented

Examples

A 46-year-old woman is going to undertake a prophylactic mastectomy for familial breast cancer
  • Ideally, in this situation you would consent her days to weeks prior to the procedure to ensure she has time to ask questions and consider her decision to undergo the procedure
  • You should gain separate written consent (i.e. complete a consent form) as well as documenting the conversation regarding risks and benefits and her expressing consent in the medical notes
  • The benefits and reasons for the procedure, the risks of the procedure itself, possible post-operative complications and the possibility of failure of treatment should all be discussed and documented

A 91-year-old man attends his GP to have his diabetic medications adjusted
  • While much less significant than a surgical procedure, you should still document the patient's consent to undergo further treatment for their diabetes in the medical notes; this can be as simple as noting they agree to change medications or doses
  • You should provide him with all the options available and allow him to make a choice based on the side effects and benefits of each medication
  • You can recommend a specific drug if you feel it is best and give your reasons for this recommendation but if he wishes to choose another treatment and decline your recommendation then you must not coerce him into following your advice

A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department unconscious after a head injury and requires emergency neurosurgery for a life-threatening intracranial bleed
  • There are two important rules to note here which is that as the patient is under 16, responsibility to consent for procedures is deferred to the parents as the law assumes she does not have the capacity to conConsent - Making decisions about investigations and treatmentsent for herself and that as this is an emergency and she is unconscious, a procedure can be done in a patient's best interests without obtaining consent
  • It would be reasonable to either discuss the procedure with her parents and gain consent from them for emergency surgery or to perform the surgery without seeking consent but to discuss the surgical plan with the parents as the relatives as you would if the patient was an adult and able to consent for themselves
  • The risks of the procedure should be explained but the key difference in explaining them here is that without surgery the patient is likely to die and so any post-operative complications are less serious than the risks of continuing without surgery
  • Time pressures mean all questions may need to be answered immediately and it is good practice to document what questions were asked of you by the relatives if any and your answers at the time; often people do not have questions and you should also document this if it is the case
  • The full discussion with the parents should be fully documented in the medical records including the main risks of performing surgery as well as the likely outcome without operative management and that formal consent from the patient themselves cannot be sought with the reasons why documented clearly

A 51-year-old man is having a benign skin lesion removed for cosmetic purposes
  • These cases where the procedure is not being carried out to increase function / prevent disability or preserve life are where consent should be most detailed
  • The benefits should be clearly listed and when discussing risks, usual surgical effects such as pain and scarring should be explained and consented for as these may cause the patient to not give consent for a purely cosmetic procedure
  • The consent process should ideally be over a number of consultations with consent being taken in advance of the procedure and confirmed on the day to ensure the patient has had time to ask any questions and is fully aware of the risks before undergoing the procedure

options: Give the F2 doctor advice about how to keep to time during a surgery
Challenge the registrar about his behaviour
Reassure the F2 doctor that this is all part of the normal banter
Advise the F2 doctor to speak to the Postgraduate Dean
Advise the F2 doctor to speak to his trainer
questions:
You are a GP registrar in a large practice with two registrars. The other registrar in the practice is constantly putting down the F2 in front of other people. Last week he made a comment about how slow the F2 is in front of the receptionists.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The GMC state the following:
'You must treat your colleagues fairly and with respect. You must not bully or harass them, or unfairly discriminate against them by allowing your personal views to affect adversely your professional relationship with them. You should challenge colleagues if their behaviour does not comply with this guidance.'

This scenario paints a picture of the other registrar bullying the F2 doctor. As stated in the GMC guidelines you have a responsibility to challenge colleagues in this situation. Advising the F2 to speak to his trainer is a good alternative but delegates the responsibility to someone else. The postgraduate dean is not ideally placed to act on the information and it is best dealt with 'in house' initially. There may be a role in informing the postgraduate dean if the registrar fails to change his behaviour.

If the F2 doctor asked you for advice about how to keep to time then of course it is helpful to share tips but this response misses the point of the question.

Harassment is not part of normal banter and should not be tolerated.
